text:
Hi, everybody. And hello to those of you out there
who will be watching this later.

You know, what I want to talk about today
is how your customers, you as partners,

are finding ways to unlock the value
of edge to cloud continuum

and and how you're finding that in terms
of accelerating for your customers and particularly accelerating
their monetization.

And your own monetization
of this continuum. For the last,
17 years, we've been delivering,

AWS have been delivering
the cloud value proposition to traditional IT customers.

And those customers have appreciated
cost efficiencies, agility, scale, security, reliability,
all the attributes of the cloud.

And we've seen this now take further
hold from regions to,

metro areas to on-prem
and to the ever expanding edge. And the edge is a
constantly redefined space.
And we see that now

there's additional need
not just to go from cloud to edge, but really to go from edge to cloud,

to take advantage of the cloud value
proposition for applications

and workloads and customers and partners
that live on the edge. They want to be able to achieve
that value in the cloud as well.

And whether that's
for a cost optimization, better customer
experiences, better business value.

I want to talk about that today. I want to talk about
how we're seeing this happen in Telco.

You know,
we've been doing it for the IT space for a very long time,
and now we're doing it for the OT space.

And it's exciting. I mean, being here this week and watching
and seeing and talking to customers

what they're doing
today, it's beyond exciting. So I'd like you to just take time
to introduce yourselves,

what you do, what this means to you,
and then we can get going.

Thanks, Wayne. So I'm Andy King,
and I work with John at Slalom.

I run our Global IoT practice
out of Emerge Next. We're an incubator for new capabilities,

and as you've alluded
to, edge and edge to cloud and hybrid edge is actually
a very important area for us to focus.
I also teach at Northeastern University and have a book out with O'Reilly Media.
So that's who I am.  Thanks for inviting. By the way, it's a good book if you haven't seen it.

Iâ€™m Iyad Tarazi CEO, Federated Wireless, we're
a software and services company

focused on shared spectrum
and private wireless. A lot of edge stuff. We are a 100% AWS
shop as well.

We've seen that interaction
between capabilities AWS has, edge deployments of applications,
and how do you actually deliver services

and software very efficiently
and at high quality at the same time. That interaction is beginning to work
and work quite well

and I'm looking forward
to talking about it. Thank you. Thanks, Wayne. I'm John Tomik. I'm a managing director here at Slalom
Consultancy.

And probably more relevant,
I am also the creator founder of Slalom Element Laboratories in New York City,
where we have been actively working

with our customers, doing some very fun
experimentation, pushing the limits for

on connectivity and compute, running things like private 5G
networks, edge compute servers,

playing around with all kinds of use cases
across all kinds of industries. I'm Debika Bhattacharya.

I am the Chief Product Officer
at Verizon Business. Verizon Business,
as you may know, is a $32

billion segment of Verizon Communications. As the product leader,
I own the segment.

I support products for all our different
B2B segments wireless, wireline
and edge compute, 5G, all the products. And we had a relationship with AWS

on the edge compute side of the business
from the early days. It's been a fantastic partnership.

So happy to be here. Thank you. Thank you all. And we also appreciate the partnerships
that we've developed over the years

with each and every one of you. Customers are generating
a tremendous amount of data at the edge,

and they really need the ability
to process that data at the edge, and they need the connectivity,
at the edge and back to the cloud.
How are you seeing customers do this? How are you seeing your partners do this?

Why is important to them? Why is it important to your businesses? Why is edge to cloud
fundamentally important today?
Sure. I'll give you an example. Nothing is better than an example. We have a deployment now with Cal Poly

University out in the West Coast. It has been an AWS shop
for quite some time,

where students and faculty have done
a lot of work on developing cloud applications and understanding
how you migrate
applications into the cloud. A student in that university

now is consuming 20 IP addresses
and about 20 times more data

than when their Wi-Fi network was built. Solving it by running fiber and cables
and Ethernet switches

and more access points
for Wi-Fi is a very expensive proposition.

Applications are not stopping. They have students that go to sleep
watching Netflix, get up,

Netflix is still running. They have students that are running gaming
sites right on their laptops.

They need data. The solution cannot be figured out, a way to move all of that to the cloud
and not have a local presence.

We've deployed for them
a private 5G network using shared spectrum,
starting with the Innovation Center,

and they're beginning now to experiment
how to move and support their students for higher data,
more applications, more fidelity

with 5G to complement their Wi-Fi network. They're using an edge compute device
from AWS.

It's part of the Snow family,
and their applications are residing on it.

Some of them are as silly as Fitbits
to track chicken in order to figure out cycles of eggs
and some of them as serious

as security cameras
for students and areas of the campus where it's not safe to walk alone.

All of that is not possible without an edge compute, and all of it is not possible
without the knowledge that they gained

by programing applications in the cloud
and taking all that knowledge, all that expertise,
all of that resident capability

and moving it seamlessly into their edge
compute application development.

That's an example.  Yeah. One of the things that we've seen at
Verizon given our significant

investment in 5G spectrum is where edge
compute is is a very natural adjacent

capability to the low latency capabilities
that 5G brings. And what we see
now, those solutions that on the edge

can enable, for example,
when we look at our connected venues,

we have cashierless checkout,
crowd analytics. We can do accelerated access.
All these applications

that use large amounts of data
and require low latency that you can only have
with the combination of 5G and edge.

And as you talked about,
starting at the edge, even in within manufacturing, within logistics,
where they're starting

to put many more cameras and they're using
intelligent video analytics,

the processing of that has to be local
and then it's only the metadata

or the anomalies or some of the analytics
that is sent to the public cloud. But all the processing happens
at the edge.

That's where it starts at the edge
and some of the data is stored in the public cloud. What we're seeing is this elastic cloud
is a term that we are using.

Our customers still want
the cloud experience, so they want the AWS experience but having the benefits
of data sovereignty, privacy,

low latency by keeping it at the edge
and having more control over it. One of the one of the themes
that I hear loudly this week is

cost optimization,
making sure that we can do this at a proper price point,
proper cost and monetization of 5G.

And we're seeing the acceleration of
the monetization of 5G and cloud together.

I would love to understand
how you see this and how your customers, how your partners, are monetizing
5G at the edge.

I can start. We have probably a pretty interesting
perspective on this because not only are

we users of all of this technology,
but we're also helping our customers kind of wade through

all of these scenarios as well. And frankly,
there was a lot of confusion out there.

What we were finding is that there were
just a lot of questions about

what kind of use cases
could take advantage of private 5G networks or public 5G networks, as well as
the compute that's required at the edge.

And so we were helping our customers
wade through all of that. I think that the value

really gets interesting
when you start to push the limits and where you start to do,

one or one of our...
just some background,  our philosophy at Slalom is,

we help our customers dream
bigger, move faster and build better tomorrow's for all. The dream bigger part
is what I get really excited about.

And I think that when you
when you take compute sitting at the edge as close to the experience
or the person or

whatever it is that you're
trying to create, and you couple that with extreme low latency and the ability
to just basically do what you want,

that's when those experiences come alive. I think the value
is really coming in, not just

traditional
how people think of monetizing, it's about that creativity that's unleashed as a result of
having the ability to work in these tools.

I'd like to pull on that
a little bit, John. I think that's a great example,
and that's something that we found too,

especially in my team,
where we focus on helping our customers get unstuck with the complexities of edge
and edge integration, edge to cloud, etc.

It boils down to creating an environment
for them to build micro experiments

that lead to a more holistic solution
in the future. And those micro experiments are
where we get to actually kick the tires

on an idea that could turn into the next
major revenue stream for our customers.

And that process that we use in order
to get to these micro experiments allows us to have, for our customers,

a reference architecture that they can
then rely upon. It really boils down to normalizing
as much as we can at the edge

to remove much of the complexity
that we typically see in a very heterogeneous environment. It's
too many different things, too many protocols

and so forth. So Snow family
is actually a great way to build a platform to support
that use case.

Teams are
building experiences. They want to bring
applications and workloads to the edge.

They want to build a better experience for their customers and a better result
for their businesses in there.

I see this every day.
I see how motivated they are. Can you give me examples
of how you're using 5G connectivity

alongside AWS' hybrid edge to deliver
these solutions, to deliver these values?

Yeah. Some of the solutions I mentioned
earlier is using AWS Wavelength.

We have them deployed across
19 locations in the US and using our 5G

connectivity to be able to to support
applications in a distributed manner.

The interesting thing is, from our perspective,
we are monetizing 5G in multiple ways. Obviously, there's 5G mobility
of over 50% of our smartphone users

have 5G capable phones,
fixed wireless access, which went from

almost
nothing to a half a billion dollars and in ten months. And then the third
area of monetization is edge.

And what we're seeing is the ability to do, to put business process on steroids
is what I call it, that you can do it.

But what we are actually seeing
is efficient business processes

that edge enables is the starting point. And many of our customers
that take an existing application

put it on the edge,
see the performance benefit, and then the next step is to re-imagine
the business process itself.

But the first step
is always to take something that they're familiar with,
improve the efficiency,

gain the financial benefits,
and then do the other steps, which is some of the more advanced
use cases.

So there are a plethora of capabilities
that we have in our portfolio to help folks
go from cloud to edge and edge to cloud.

but I'd like to hear more about
how are you all applying the set of services, a set of capabilities
we have, to deliver this value between

your customers, you as partners,
and us as AWS. I'll add to it.

I agree 100% with what you said. It really is about efficiency. There are really three
big drivers today for

5G extension, if you would,
whether it's public or private. One is automation. There's just not enough workers out there.

And there's a real big need
for automation. Warehousing probably is one of the
leading sectors for automation.

We have deployed a warehouse application
now for the DOD.
It's a million square feet. It has five types of robotics on it,

a full workforce automation, as well. They went from 150 people
to about four people that are going to be

running the entire warehouse. If you can imagine a Humvee coming
in, being broken down into 300 components,

each component is logged
and moved around with robots and then re-shipped,
in order to be retrofitted and come back.

That's sort of the operations they have. It cannot be done with humans anymore. They're just not enough
engineers who are wanting to get out

and be working or any entry level people that want to work out
in these warehouses anymore.

The robotics solutions cannot be done
without edge compute. All the data gets logged right there.

That edge compute is useless
without a cloud application to manage a nationwide
inventory management systems.

You need seamless applications
to move between the cloud and edge. You also need all the enablement of 5G.

You need the integration
between public and private networks. You also need the applications
themselves, the barcode readers

and all of the other devices that exist
in the Amazon marketplace, for example. That marriage between operators and cloud
companies to bring the best of what

they have together into one marketplace
is what's going to monetize 5G.

And just to add a point
on that, monetization networks as always comes later after you build it.
For whatever reason we do that ourselves.

4G was built
and then the iPhone came in to generate the monetization model primarily
by bringing a million developers

into the system that found a way to come
generate the data for us to monetize it.

5G is going to be monetized, in my view,
with a million SI's and small

applications
and 5G solutions, warehouse automations, and other agricultural applications
that will need a framework,

which is very similar to this marriage
that we see today between operators and cloud companies, to
create an environment that allow for that.

We're at the tipping
point of monetizing 5G. And that is really through
extending the ecosystem as far as we can.

I couldn't agree more. In fact,
we're just like your example, Debika,

we're seeing kind of an interesting
hybrid version of that as well.

I'll give you a great example. So we worked with one of the biggest water
utilities on the West Coast and they came to us
with a very simple question.

They came to us asking, "Look, we don't
we don't have the greatest connectivity,

but we have a lot of facilities,
we have a lot of processes, we have issues
that we need to really solve for.

And what we're not sure of is what do we need,
what kind of infrastructure do we need?"
And so taking that very broad statement and figuring out how to apply

5G networks, edge compute devices that will unlock those 
kinds of use cases was really exciting.

And it's really the creativity
that this unlocks as well, because I agree,
there's a lot of confusion around,

how do you bring
these kinds of things to market. And what we're seeing is
that it's just an exciting time

where our clients are starting to realize that they can actually do the things
now that they've always wanted to do.

For example, we were doing some remote inspections of water treatment facilities
where there was little to no connectivity

and they were actually taking a leapfrog
from having very little into something where you're using augmented
reality devices in real time,

with training solutions and a tier two operator in another state
that was helping them navigate through

how to troubleshoot
turning on a well pump. It's vital that we deliver value. It's fundamental.

You know, technologies are fun,
they're interesting. But if we don't deliver value
to our customers,

it's just an exercise. You've learned a lot. What I'd like to understand
is, you know, what lessons would you like

to convey to the folks that are watching.
In your experience of delivering 5Gâ€™s value, edge
value, and cloud value together?

What can we teach them both
in terms of building and go to market? What I'm saying, I was going to say
is, what we've learned,

it's been, you know, a couple of years
since we've been working on this. First of all, it's think big, start small.

Because a lot of times people want to, they want to start
with a transformational use case.

And that requires a lot of integration,
a lot of work, a lot of pieces have to come together
that just delays the start of the project.

But if you take something
that seems relatively mundane, but build the infrastructure,
then the other use

cases can be added on
with minimal additional cost. The other thing that we've learned is,

some of these use cases are horizontal. I talked about our accelerated access, which was designed for venues
to allow fans to come in

and do facial authentication
so that there's it's frictionless. You don't have to go through turnstiles.

But that same application on talking to
other customers can be used in logistics and in distribution companies
that have a lot of temp drivers.

So they use that for access control
and it's still on the edge, but now it's on the private edge
instead of the public edge.

So I love seeing how in a use case
that may start in one industry, is horizontal and gets fed/
translated to a different industry,

but using the same underlying enablers, but really helping the
business challenge.

I think that's a great point
and it's something that we see oftentimes where we start working with our customers

to help them
realize the big vision that they've got. And yet we prefer to start small.
Let's actually run a micro experiment. And what happens, oftentimes, we start down this path.

We start looking at what is the use case
and who's going to benefit from this. What are the KPIs that we want to track
that can show the business some value?

And then we find that oftentimes,
a micro pivot, not even orthogonal,
but a micro pivot from that original idea

is actually going to be more optimal
than what they were originally thinking.

Yet we still don't lose
sight of that big vision. And so again, I think that
some of the services that we've been able

to employ from AWS, whether it's Greengrass Core, 
Greengrass 2.0,

of the direct connectivity
into Kinesis to stream data,

access to IoT core using the MQTT protocol and whatnot.
Setting up that infrastructure,

not with a build it
and they will come mindset, but setting it up
because the integration piece is hard.

We know we're going to need it
to achieve that bigger vision, and then run these micro experiments
to show how the data is going to flow,

how we can process it at the edge,
and then get that value, that metadata you were talking about earlier,
into the cloud for further analysis

where we can
horizontally scale ad infinitum. That to me is really been the value
of the AWS services that we've leaned on

and the process that we use
to basically think big and start small. I love that. I think the Snow family is ideal
for what we're talking about.

Start right away with one application
and start playing with it. I'm just amazed how much of our customers
already know what they want to do.

They just don't know how to go about it. I see people walking in to say,
"Let's try to design the next three years."

Which is not the people on this panel,
obviously, but the people that we see around us that
will get stuck into designing forever.

And I see people coming in to say, well,
here's a quick network. Start tomorrow.

Find out how far you can take
your application. That's what I love about the Snow family. It comes in different forms.

It can come ruggedized,
it can come all sorts of ways. But the idea of starting small
and be fully connected to the rest

of your Amazon experience
and the rest of your other experiences, let your engineers play with it
pretty quickly,

they'll find out whether the security camera
is appropriate or not. I'd love to pick up on that. I also love think big, start small,
because that is been the success

for many customers for the last 17 years in leveraging the cloud
computing paradigm.

If you think big and try to act big,
you generally don't get anything done. You're absolutely right.

Given that,  connectivity is a continuum, cloud
computing is a continuum. Years ago we did not talk about
regions to edge, but

the world evolves. Our customers of all our partners evolve. We evolve
because we listen to what you're saying,

and we deliver the services
that are important so that you can build your solutions
and businesses on top of.

Given that we live on a continuum, it's
not a big bang. If you were to look back

a couple of years, we'll say five years,
you can go with three if you want. What would you tell yourselves
about today?
What would you do differently? What would you do the same?

How would you help the
folks that are out there today, listening? When they think about themselves today and what they think about themselves
five years from now?

What acceleration do you want to see them
appreciate from your experience?

If I can start from a connectivity
standpoint, we actually took a page from AWS in terms of how our customers
view network or procure network.

Historically, it was very component
and circuit and very static.

And where we are today compared to three
or even five years ago is, network
is a service and our customers shouldn't worry about the specific technology.

They should only worry
about the outcome. And the provider takes ownership of providing the
the service as they need it.
The SLA is the outcome. They can flex up and down. They can they can reconfigure their needs

you know, based on their application. So that now, we are building programable network
so the application can now talk directly,

you know, even before network
slicing comes into play to make sure that the network is adaptable
to what's needed.

So these are the new aspects of networking
which a lot of it all and a lot of the learnings
came from the cloud industry to make it

easy, make it dynamic, make it intuitive and give the control of it
back to the users and the applications.

That's exciting to
to marry these network attributes with cloud attributes.

Yeah. Five years ago when I told myself
I would have said that 5G is a national security issue,
which I wouldn't have predicted.

I would have also told myself
the fragmentation in the ecosystem is going to be far worse
than you would think, Iyad. And it truly is.

Everybody's in 5G business today. Probably even the local pizza
joint is probably going to be in the 5G

business soon. What's going to happen in five years,
fragmentation is going to get out of control, but there will be frameworks
provided by operators

and cloud companies to organize the masses
in order for it to make sense to users.

And I would also say the power of the enterprise
and the user in determining their own

applications, solutions, and destiny
in 5G is only going to go up from here.

Five years ago, I would have told myself, actually, I
would have taken the advice of the client

that I was speaking about, this water
utility. He had a great phrase, "Just take the leap."

Take the leap, because what we're exploring right now
is a truly creative space.

And there are a lot of issues. The fragmentation is absolutely -
we see that in a big, big way.

I was surprised at how a lot of the network
technologies were outpacing
the devices this time, and that was interesting to run into.
But it shouldn't stop you, right? I think the...

My only regret is that
we didn't jump in and create what we created and got customers
thinking about this sooner.

Because I think the sooner you jump into
this and you'll run into all kinds of issues, you're going to

try to do something, you're
going to try and build an experience and you'll run into a situation where

there isn't a device that's going
to be able to do what you want it to do. And now you're actually thinking about
manufacturing or fabricating something

to create the experience
that you're that you want to do. But again, that's it's
that's the wonderful part of creation.

I think that we're just in a really amazing time
right now where

the compute components,
they're all there. The software components, they're all
there. The networking components,

They're there. What was missing
and what is actually got created a couple of years ago
was this flurry of inspiration
and flurry of creativity that is now just exciting to kind of ride the wave on.

And I think, certainly if I could go back in time
five years, I would be telling myself

some of the same things
I'm telling myself now. Integration is hard.
But to pull on what you all are

saying, why are you waiting? Why are you looking at the integration
as the long pole in the tent?

It is, but let's get started. Let's actually create a steel thread
and we pull it through all the things

that we know we need to touch in order
to solve a particular problem and use that as the driver for addressing
those integration challenges.

It moves us forward quickly,
but it doesn't force us to lose sight of our great vision, for
that product, whatever it's going to be.

And so that integration piece
has so many different elements to it. Yes, it's hard,
but if we don't get started

working a solution
based on that steel thread driving towards that ultimate vision, then
we're not going to actually get there.

We're going to focus too much time
on trying to solve point solutions and not ultimately get to
where we need to be as a business.

So I would give myself that advice
and say, look, you really need to focus on the integration piece
in terms of the bigger picture,

not just solving one particular point
solution. Well, I'm looking forward to coming back
here, you know, five years from now

and asking ourselves the same question
and asking our customers and our partners
the same question as well.

You know, for 17
years, AWS has been delivering cloud value propositions
and today we're delivering

that alongside you,
from cloud to edge and edge to cloud. You know, we've helped transform the
IT industry.

A lot of the questions
that the telcos and and telco industry folks are asking today around,
is it possible? Can I do it?

Is it real? With the same questions
that, you know, their peers in the I.T.

side of the house 17 years ago were asking. And today
those questions aren't asked.
Is it cost effective? Can it be more agile? Is it secure, is it reliable?
Does it really drive innovation? And those questions aren't asked anymore.
They're not the questions on top of mind. It's how can we do more? Tell me how we can get this done.

I know we can. And this industry is in this place
right now. And you folks are the trailblazers.

You're the leaders. You're demonstrating
that this is possible now. And what excites me being here
this week is seeing what you're doing,
what all the folks are doing and all, the booths across the entire show. It's simply mind blowing.

And if I could tell myself, 
my five year

younger person, which I relish thinking
about that for a minute,

I would be more of an evangelist. I would get out
and talk to more customers. I would bring more examples

of how people are succeeding
so that they can get inspired to do what you all are doing with your customers
and with us as partners.

I want to thank you for being here
today. I hope that all of this inspires people out there to know
that this is not a pipe dream, right?

We're really taking telco and making it, to use a phrase,
technology companies

and I love the point about,
taking the network and turning it into a resource
that application and workload developers

can leverage in the same way they leverage
all resources they do today on the cloud.
It's a tremendous model.

I want to thank all of you
and I want inspire the people out there to really listen to what you said
and to not have any reservation

about engaging you and engaging others
and realizing the power of edge

to cloud, the power of 5G connectivity,
and the marriage between those. So thank you very much. Thank you.
